thread.title: H.S. football: Chaotic sequence in BC-Joe's game
thread.title_full: H.S. football: Chaotic sequence in BC-Joe's game

title: H.S. football: Chaotic sequence in BC-Joe's game
text:
H.S. football: Chaotic sequence in BC-Joe's game October 26, 2015 Last updated: Monday, October 26, 2015, 1:21 AM The Record 
There was a bit of controversy at the end of regulation in Bergen Catholic's 16-13 overtime victory against St. Joseph. 
It centered around clock stoppage and timeouts. 
St. Joseph, leading 10-7, had just been called for a face-mask penalty at the end of a run by Bergen Catholic's Ryan McCarthy. The clock was stopped as the officials marked off the penalty down to the St. Joseph 6-yard line, still shy of a first down. 
With 21 seconds remaining, BC coach Nunzio Campanile began walking out on the field thinking he was granted a timeout. 
"I actually intended to call a timeout, then I realized I didn't have one," Campanile said. "They stopped the clock for the first down/penalty. They stopped the clock so I started walking out there." 
The officials were trying to figure out if it was a first down, so the clock wasn't running. St Joseph coach Augie Hoffmann said the clock never should've stopped, but acknowledged the Crusaders still probably would've had a chance to run another play before attempting a field goal. 
"It was hysteria over there," Hoffmann said. "At the end of the day, they still would have had time to try the field goal, but you just don't know what would've happened." 
Bergen Catholic freshman Mike Kearney kicked a 21-yard field goal as time expired to tie the game at 10 and force overtime. 
â€” Mark J. Czerwinski and Darren Cooper
